metadata.case_name: Appellant v. Happy Home Cooperative Housing Society Ltd.

facts.text: Happy Home Cooperative Housing Society Ltd. registered in February 1949.
Society obtained lease of land measuring about 12,000 sq. yards at Nehru Road, Vile Parle East, Bombay.
Society divided land into 17 plots for members to build houses, members obligated to pay premium, annual rent of Re. 1/-, incidental charges.
Society advanced loans to members for construction, repayable in monthly installments with interest.
Plot No. 10, 676 sq. yds., allotted to appellant.
Appellant constructed house on Plot No. 10 through Society's agency, completed and occupied on or about May 1, 1951.
Society advanced loan of Rs. 26,922/- odd to appellant.
Agreement dated March 26, 1952, between appellant and Society regarding loan, registered on May 27, 1952.
Agreement provided for repayment in 366 or fewer monthly installments; after full repayment, Society to execute sub-lease of Plot No. 10.
Default clause: Society could determine agreement on installment default, forfeit payments, require surrender of possession.
No installments paid by appellant.
Society issued notice on August 26, 1954, calling for vacant possession; appellant did not comply.
Society referred dispute to Registrar under s. 54 Bombay Co-operative Societies Act, 1925.
Committee of Arbitrators appointed: nominee of Society (plaintiff), nominee of appellant (defendant), Registrar's nominee (Chairman).
Arbitrators' award by majority: appellant to deliver vacant possession of Plot No. 10 and house, pay Rs. 150/- per month compensation from October 1, 1954, to delivery; liable for arbitration costs.
Appellant filed revisional application to Bombay Co-operative Tribunal, contending dispute was landlord-tenant under s. 28 Bombay Rents Act, 1947; Tribunal dismissed.
Award certified under s. 59 Act, filed for execution in Bombay City Civil Court.
Appellant took Chamber Summons for stay of execution; Judge held award without jurisdiction per s. 28 Rent Act, made summons absolute on October 16, 1956.
Society appealed to Bombay High Court, First Appeal No. 685 of 1956; Division Bench reversed on March 12, 1959, held no landlord-tenant relationship, directed execution with costs.
High Court granted certificate; appeal to Supreme Court.
Society's lease from Government for 999 years from March 17, 1950, annual rent Rs. 6,264/-; land mortgaged to Government.
Agreement preamble: appellant to pay Rs. 10,020/- in installments for plot transfer; loan up to Rs. 16,980/- for construction.
Sub-lease for 998 years only after full repayment and Government consent.

legal_issues.text: Whether the agreement dated March 26, 1952 created a relationship of landlord and tenant between the appellant and the Society.
Whether the Award made under Bombay Co-operative Societies Act was without jurisdiction due to s. 28 of Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rents Control Act, 1947.

petitioner_arguments.text: Agreement created landlord-tenant relationship; dispute regarding possession and rent falls under exclusive jurisdiction of Small Causes Court per s. 28 Rent Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 28 Bombay Rents Act 57 of 1947; s. 27-A Specific Relief Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if Society did not claim landlord-tenant, appellant's plea of tenancy displaces arbitrators' jurisdiction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 28 Bombay Rents Act 57 of 1947; Babulal Bhuramal v. Nandram Shivram

respondent_arguments.text: Agreement was only an agreement to lease, executory contract; sub-lease only after full payment; no present demise or landlord-tenant relationship.
Dispute was regarding default in loan repayment and membership cessation, not landlord-tenant; arbitrators had jurisdiction under Co-operative Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 54, s. 59 Bombay Co-operative Societies Act VII of 1925

court_reasoning.text: Agreement construed as whole is executory contract for future sub-lease upon full payment and Government consent; no present lease despite 'tenant' description.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Real nature determined by construction of document as whole, not particular words.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant defaulted, did not qualify for sub-lease; Society could terminate and reclaim possession under agreement.
Society did not claim tenancy before arbitrators; sought possession for default and membership cessation; appellant's plea does not oust jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 28 applies only if claimant alleges landlord-tenant relationship.

court_reasoning.text: Babulal case does not support ouster of jurisdiction by defendant's tenancy plea alone.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Exclusive jurisdiction arises from plaintiff's claim of tenancy.

holdings.text: No landlord-tenant relationship; agreement is executory contract for sub-lease post full payment.
Arbitrators had jurisdiction; Award valid and executable.

precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished; does not support ouster of jurisdiction by defendant's tenancy plea.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Co-operative Societies Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs reference of dispute to Registrar, arbitration, certification of award as decree.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rents Control Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Exclusive jurisdiction of Small Causes Court for landlord-tenant suits re possession/rent; does not apply here.

statutes_cited.name: Specific Relief Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Cited by appellant for defending possession without registered lease; not upheld.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld High Court judgment reversing stay on execution of arbitration award, held no landlord-tenant relationship and arbitrators had jurisdiction; directed execution to proceed.
outcome.relief_granted: Execution of award in favour of Society to proceed.
outcome.costs: Costs to Society in both courts (as per High Court order upheld).

key_quotes.text: It is well-settled that the real nature of a transaction has to be determined on a proper construction of the document as a whole and not upon any particular words used in the document.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle for interpreting the agreement.

key_quotes.text: The agreement construed as a whole leaves no manner of doubt that it was an agreement... to grant a sub-lease... only after the appellant had fulfilled his part of the agreement.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The exclusive jurisdiction of the Court of Small Causes arises only if the person invoking the jurisdiction... alleges that the other party is a tenant or a landlord.
key_quotes.speaker: court
